Fields.DialogueText: Whoa, that's a lot of fish you're frying there!
No ba - it looks like my patience with fishing finally paid off.
It smells really good - but shouldn't you do something about that smoke?
Oh! Down, down! Okay, it should be fine now.
No need to get too worked up. I just thought you were smoking the food or something like that.
No, I'd been considering it, but I decided on sugar and pepper instead.
Sugar and spice, and everything nice, huh? Exactly what sort of dish are you preparing?
Gefilte. It's a traditional recipe among the Jewish population back home.
Interesting. I can't wait to try some.
Just wait until it's all finished. I made enough for everybody to have a fair share.

Fields.MenuText: You know, these patties remind me a lot of your sausages.
Isn't the dish meant for an appetizer, though? You're grilling quite a bunch there.
Why both sugar and spice?

Fields.DialogueText: No surprise – that's my specialty, after all.
Don't worry - once we split things evenly, the serving size will be reduced a bit.
That's kind of an experiment on my part. They use sugar or spice depending on the region, so I decided to combine them together.
Anyway, that's really generous of you, sharing your food with everyone.
Well, I want to keep the flame alive, even if the lights are going out elsewhere. But never mind that, could you give me a hand with the frying pan?
Sure thing. But we should probably wrap things up soon. I just got word that a Morgana group is on its way here.
Looks like we have other "fish" to fry, then. Let's get going.
@BATTLE
Nie, that's not quite right. Maybe if I...
What are you working on over here, Wicher? It looks sort of like your paper cuttings, somewhat.
Oh, more star stuff. I was talking before about bigger projects? This seemed like one I might try scaling up.
I see. Although, you never really explained what you were up to with it before.
I didn't, did I? It's kind of complicated.
That's okay, I'm a good listener.
Okay. I want to make a sort of universal map for the stars.
Hasn't that already been done?
Not exactly. The stars are always moving, so you are always seeing something different when you chart them out. Not to mention the different views from around the world.
Ah, that makes sense. But how are you going to get past that issue?
I was thinking to make a mobile map.
One that you can move accordingly? So that's why you're working with the paper carvings.
Dokladnie - you're absolutely right. It's kind of tricky, though. I'm still in the drafting stage.

Fields.MenuText: What made you so interested in the stars?
It all sounds pretty complex and challenging.
Isn't this arrangement a little fragile? A small gust of wind could blow the papers away.

Fields.DialogueText: They've always inspired me with their determination. Even after they die, their light lives on for much longer, continuing to inspire others.
Yes, but it is a challenge I intend to overcome. If I can do this, I can make my own mark in natural philosophy.
I certainly know the power of the gale, but such is the way of life. We are always under threat, but we can still rebuild, over and over.
Well, I'll be interested to see what it's like when it's finished. And you know I'll help if I can.
Thank you. I think it will be a beauty when I'm through.
Maps are certainly useful, and if you can get one that's workable to the situation, that will really come in handy. I just wish we could do the same with the Morganas.
Yes, they always seem to show up right out of the blue, don't they?
@BATTLE
Kapitan, could you please help me put these books on some shelves?
Sure. Are you working on a library or something?
In a way. It started out just with books I have been having sent from Poland – before they get burned by the invaders – but I want to include other people's works as well.
Interesting. By the way, how did you wish to organize it?
... I don't know.
That's okay, I was just curious.
No, it's a valid question. But I am unsure which means of arrangement would be best.
Can't you just pick one and go with it?
Tak. Sure. But I want all the books to be valued equally. If I choose one system, others are going to be ordered and marginalized accordingly.

Fields.MenuText: Do you really need to organize them, then?
They're just books, not people.
Just choose a method and go with it. You can still give them equal treatment by reading them and caring for them.

Fields.DialogueText: You know I prefer to have an order to things. Then again, perhaps chaos has its own order.
Yes, but they capture the hearts of their writers. Still, maybe I am getting too worked up over this.
Good point. It doesn't really matter in the end.
Thank you for the advice. I think I know what to do.
So, where do you want me to put these ones?
Over... on the desk.
The desk? Why the desk?
Because we'll need to do the arranging later. There are Morganas dead ahead.
@BATTLE
Those are some cute flower crowns there.
Dziekuje ci - thanks! Do you like any one of them in particular?
Well, I think they would all look nice on you.
That's not what I meant. I was wondering if you wanted one.
Me?
Tak. You see, I'm just content with one crown. I made these others for my friends.
Oh, I get it now.
So, which one would you like?

Fields.MenuText: The one with the corn poppy.
The iris crown.
The seerose one.

Fields.DialogueText: Wear that one with solemnity, so we can remember our fellow comrades who have fallen.
It is a rather precious one, isn't it? I just hope that it continues to blossom back home.
The paper one? It's artificial, but it still has its own flair to it, I must admit.
Your flower garden must be thriving, then.
Yes, the flowers are doing quite well. It helps that I'm doing my best to take care of them.
Well, that was never in question. You always do your best to look after other living things.
Dziekuje ci. It's helped that you all have been around to assist me.
Hey, what are friends for?
Quite right. That's why I made the crowns.
Then let's show these Morganas the power of our friendship.
@BATTLE
Oh, hello, Kapitan!
Hello, Wicher. What's with the blankets?
I just thought they would come in handy.
Wait, are you going to try to take over shifts for the crew again? I told you that we need to balance things out so everyone can stay healthy.
Nie - not exactly. You see, some of the girls saw that I was kind of worn down, so they offered a compromise.
What would that be?
They said that they could handle their shifts, but they were fine if I wanted to rest by them out there. That way, I can be on hand if anything comes up.
I see. It's still bending the rules a little.
I know, and I feel bad about it, but I just wanted to help them. Is it okay with you?

Fields.MenuText: I am just worried that you won't be able to get enough sleep out on deck.
It's kind of like a slumber party then. Hope you have fun!
Don't be. I'm glad that you found a way to please everyone.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't worry, I enjoy feeling the gale against my face.
Yes, I'm really looking forward to bonding with them more.
Thank you. I like sticking to protocol, but sometimes it's fun to try new things.
Just make sure you don't get washed overboard.
I'll be fine. Besides, it's not like we get much sleep anyway with the Morganas on the prowl around the clock.
You've got me there. And, here are some now!
@BATTLE
There! That should do it!
Writing a letter?
Tak - back to headquarters in Poland.
Oh, I see. What did you say to them, given your current concerns?
Just my usual report on things out here, and a request to stay informed in turn.
You didn't ask at all about being reassigned?
There's no point in doing so. What's done is done. At this point, it would be just as heartbreaking for me to leave all of you to fight the Morganas alone.

Fields.MenuText: Still, I think that they would appreciate knowing how you feel.
We can handle ourselves out here if you want to deal with your home's issues.
You won't know if you don't try.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right, but I also don't want to trouble them. They have enough to worry about as it is.
I'm not sure if I would make much of a difference at this point. Contemplating what ifs is interesting, but the best philosophy keeps things in the present.
I know, but I have made my decision already. I want to fight the Morganas with the fleet and protect the world, even if I can't protect my own home.
Sorry about how things are going for you.
It's okay. I just need to keep my spirits up.
Don't worry. Maybe you can find a way for your work out here to make a difference back in Poland.
Perhaps. I'll need to think about it. For the moment, the Morganas give us no rest.
@BATTLE
Wicher, what's with all this smoke? I thought you hated having it around.
This is steam, not smoke. The two are very different.
Still, makes it tough to see where I'm going – aa!
Careful, Kapitan. Are you okay?
Just all washed up. What is all this?
I want to make a spa onboard so people can relax after the fights.
A spa on a ship? Isn't that kind of over the top?
Perhaps, but I thought it would be something really fun for people to enjoy together.

Fields.MenuText: You should have asked before you got started.
This is a tribute to your home, isn't it?
Just as long as you manage things okay. Steam might not be the same as smoke, but both can be a hazard if not controlled.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sorry, Kapitan. It just came to me all of a sudden.
Yes. There's a wonderful spa in Gdynia that gave me the inspiration for this.
Don't worry, I'll make sure that things run smoothly.
All right, it's not a bad idea. We could all use a little relaxation now and then.
Thank you, Kapitan. Dziekuje ci. I'm sorry about the steam getting out of control. We should be clear now.
Yes, I can see now – and I see some Morganas on the hunt!
@BATTLE
There you are, Kapitan. I wanted to get your permission for a training program.
Oh? You want to start up a school on board?
Tak - with your permission. I have some experience as a school ship, so I thought I could give it another try out here.
We could all use a little training. What did you have in mind for the regimen?
Actually, that's part of what I wanted to talk to you about. I was thinking of a more collaborative training program.
I like the sound of that. It'll fit in well with your cultural exchange idea.
Exactly. I just hope that I'm up to the challenge.

Fields.MenuText: Even if you do have your weak points, you can count on the rest of us to cover for you.
You have a very passionate and strong spirit Wicher, so I know you'll be a great instructor.
Go for it. I know this means a lot to you.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. That's the beauty of teamwork.
Thanks you. I'll put my full effort into it.
It does. Even if the process is difficult, it needs to be done if we want to win for good.
Okay, you have my approval.
Wspaniale! I'll start rounding up the girls for the training.
Say, do you think I could be a part of it as well?
Sure, why not? But first, let's start with some target practice.
@BATTLE
Brrr! This wind is chilling me to the bones.
Come on, Kapitan, it's not that bad. In fact, I feel that it's quite wonderful out!
Wonderful, my foot. The wind is blowing everything around like crazy.
That's exactly my point. Seeing the weather go wild like this always fills me with energy.
Funny how you can love this chaos so much, but you can get so stuck on following orders sometimes.
Like I said with science and art, why can't I be both? I can be as sturdy as stone if I need to be, or as free as the wind.

Fields.MenuText: Not the best comparison out here – stones and wind can both sink a ship.
Well, I guess we all have things we enjoy, even if we don't all share the same opinion.
Just make sure that the ship doesn't get blown off course.

Fields.DialogueText: Okay, maybe not metaphorically, but my point still stands.
My point exactly. I mean, some of you guys like smoke of all things.
Not to worry. I know the charts like the back of my hand.
Well, at least the wind's finally dying down.
Oh, pooh! Things were starting to get fun.
That's strange, though. Why do I still feel a chill down my spine?
Because even if the natural phenomena are calming down, the unnatural ones are still at it.
It doesn't look like too many of them, though, so let's push through them like a gale.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, could you give me a hand with these things?
Sure. But what are you doing with all this ju... stuff?
I'm trying to build a collaborative museum on board.
A museum, huh? You have a lot of interesting ideas.
Museums are very nice – I heard about several of them when I was at Tallinn. It's a great way to help preserve our different histories for the future.
I'm not sure we'll have enough stuff for a museum out here, though. Besides, do we have enough room?
That's why I'm planning it out right now with some sketches - but do you think you could help me with these first few loads?

Fields.MenuText: You'll have to be careful with these. Sea conditions aren't exactly the best place for artifacts.
Well, you certainly have the sense of organization it takes for this sort of undertaking.
What will we do with the museum when the war is over?

Fields.DialogueText: Which is why I intend to go strictly by the book in regard to the treatment procedures. So, please, be careful how you handle those!
Dziekuje ci - you're very kind. That's what made me decide to do this. It's one way I can help preserve the diversity of this world, even out here.
Bring it back to Poland with me, maybe? Or perhaps a world tour. It kind of depends on how things end up post-war.
So, what's in these boxes, anyway? Wait, are these what I think they are?
Priceless treasures from Poland. They managed to sneak a few of them out.
I see. I'll do my best to help you look after them.
Dziekuje ci - you're doing me a real favor. I wish that they didn't have to be dragged out to a battlefield, but they're probably safer here.
Kind of ironic that it's safer out here with the Morganas.
Well, relatively safer. We can't let our guard down, or they'll catch us on the flank, like now.
@BATTLE
Dozing off, again, Wicher?
Zzz... Kapitan! Sorry about that!
I thought I was clear about the importance of getting enough rest?
You were, but I've decided to start taking naps regularly so that I can be on hand in case of emergencies.
That's an interesting approach. Although it almost looked as if you were meditating.
Sleep is a form of contemplation for me, a place where the conscious and subconscious blur.
Does that have anything to do why you have that notebook next to you?
It does. Sometimes I try to write – or sketch – my dreams after I wake up.

Fields.MenuText: Trying to see if they foretell anything?
Good that you can write them down. I forget them as soon as I wake up.
What sort of dreams are you having?

Fields.DialogueText: Not really. Even if fortune telling works, the interpretation would depend on the individual – a storm could mean either good or bad luck since there will be a rainbow.
You just have to get into the habit of forcing yourself to remember.
All sorts of things. Sometimes nightmares, sometimes more hopeful visions.
Well, it looks like you woke up at just the right time. We have some Morganas to eliminate.
Now I wish that I was back in my dream!
Take it easy. These Morganas may think that they're nightmares, but soon they'll be haunted by us in their dreams.
@BATTLE
Wicher, are you okay? I came as soon as I heard the blast!
I'm fine. Just help me fan away the smoke, please?
Sure, let me help. What was that?
I was experimenting with some vodka.
Vodka? I thought you preferred French liqueur instead.
Vodka is a national tradition! Besides, I thought that the vodka would be useful for combat purposes.
Just as long as we don't blow ourselves up first.
No ba. I think I made the last batch a little too volatile. Still, the remainder can work well as a seasoning.
You have a way of finding use for everything, don't you?
It's an important quality as a soldier. If you're outnumbered, you need to be able to use anything you can in order to hold out.
Like back home?
Tak. I just wish we had more hope of winning. Even though we keep coming up with trick after trick, the end seems near.

Fields.MenuText: If anything can be used as a weapon, maybe you can find something out here to use to defend your country.
I hear that vodka can be used for cosmetics as well.
The battle's never over, even if we lose.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. I'll see if I can think of a solution.
And medicine, though the exact terminology has shifted over the years. It just goes to show that everything has its ups and downs.
You're right. They may say that we are defeated, but we will never give up.
Anyway, make sure the rest of the bottles are safely stowed before...
*BOOM*
Wicher!
That wasn't me this time.
More Morganas? You may be able to put your drink to good use now.
@BATTLE
Let's see... What rhymes with "sztokfisz?"
Oh, hey, Wicher. What are you up to?
I'm working on some poetry. Sung poetry, to be precise.
You mean like a ballad? That's pretty neat.
I'm making one about our experiences out here. When I'm done, I am going to send it back home to give the people a little more hope.
That sounds great. Need any help?
I think I'm doing okay so far. Do you think they'll appreciate it, though? It's not the same as me actually being there.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure that they will appreciate the thought you put into it.
It has a chance of cheering them up, and you need to take every chance you can get.
You're smart, so I know that you'll figure things out.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. It's not much, but it's at least something I can do for the war effort.
That's right. If it has the slightest chance of making things better, I'll do it.
Thank you.
It might be interesting if we all make poems to commemorate our experiences at sea, and of our homes.
No ba.... Not a bad idea. We could make a record of some of them for our library, too.
You know, I wonder if the Morganas make any poetry.
It's probably centered around misery. Which has its own beauty, but it's better to stay optimistic for a better future.
Indeed. They won't get us to give up, no matter what they throw at us.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, do you think you could look at and sign this petition I'm working on?
Maybe. What's it for, a smoking ban on board?
Nie - this is for something more serious.
Oh. It must be, for you to get worked up over that.
I have my prejudices, but this is too important to let that, or anything else, get in the way.
Okay, let's take a look. "Winds of Change: A Call for True Peace Everywhere." What is this?
It is a petition for all of the sides involved to end the fighting, not only out here but on land as well.
I don't know. It sounds like it would be pretty difficult to pull off.
It will be, certainly, but it must be done. Too much is at stake! Not only in my home, but across the globe.
But what can we do out here?
In our truce at sea, we are the best symbol that we currently have for peace – well, except when we fight against the Morganas. If we present a united front, we might be able to push for real change.

Fields.MenuText: There's a lot of literal ground to cover for any agreement to work, though.
Isn't this something that can be done after we're finished out here?
You're right, this is critical. Maybe this will actually work.

Fields.DialogueText: Not as much as you think. We've already obtained peace on the oceans, and those make up the majority of the planet.
No, we have to start now if we want to get anything done. If we stall, it may be too late.
It's a longshot, I admit, but I have faith in it working. If we can get the people to see and take action, the elites running this whole gambit will have to change their ways, or else!
Okay, here's my signature for the lot. You'll need to convince a lot more people – and ships – if you want to make this work.
I'm already on it. It will be tough with some of the other soldiers – we all feel a sense of obligation to our countries, but I think I can help them see the light.
You're willing to work with them, even now?
Of course. If they can find the strength to stand up for justice and the common being, I will welcome them with open arms. It's those who let others die in their place that I despise.
Well, in any case, we're also going to need to finish this war with the Morganas if we want things to be safe, peace treaty or not.
Luckily, they don't have the sense to stay away. If they keep trying to ambush us like that, we'll have them whipped in the end.
@BATTLE
Wicher, where are you? We kind of have a situation up here.
I'm coming, I'm coming - wah!
Watch it! You almost cut my hand with those scissors!
Przepraszam! Sorry! I was working on more of my paper cutting when the attack started, and I wanted to get up here as soon as I could.
Still, have you ever heard the saying "haste makes waste?"
That's why I'm usually more cautious in this regard. Maybe I should go back to my normal approach.
That's not exactly what I meant...
I know, but I don't want anyone to get hurt from my mistakes.

Fields.MenuText: Just go at the pace that works best for you. I won't get upset either way.
Maybe you should work for a balance between efficiency and quality.
As long as you're a little more careful, I think you'll do okay.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain. I'll try to be myself and decide on the best approach for me.
Good point. It's best to find a moderate balance for things in life.
Thanks you, Kapitan. I'll be more considerate without slowing down that much.
Well, the point is you're here now. So let's get down to business.
Right. I've got the scissors stowed safely away, and I'm ready to go.
Then see if you can cut these enemy ships to shreds.
@BATTLE
Come back!
Wicher, what's – look out!
Got it! Huh? Oh, I'm sorry, Kapitan. Przepraszam. I didn't mean to bump into you like that.
It's okay. What was the trouble?
A stray gust of wind carried off a few of my charts. Luckily, I managed to catch the last one just now.
That's good. So you're still at it, huh? You're certainly tenacious.
Well, the star mapping in particular means a lot to me.
Because it helps you give a sense of order to things?
Partially, but also because it gives me a link to home.
How's that?
See? Here is a chart of the stars from where we are, and this is one from Gdynia. By connecting them together, it seems like I am really not that far away after all.

Fields.MenuText: It's amazing how you stay so bright! I just hope we can all see our homes again.
What really impresses me, is how you jump back up from each setback more determined than ever.
I can't wait to see what it's like when you're finished.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't give up. The stars are surrounded by darkness, yet they are all part of a larger story. As long as we hold onto our bonds and fight to protect them, we'll find our way home.
It's the spirit of my homeland. It is a determination to stand up, no matter how many times you are beaten down. In this hour, it may be our last hope.
Thanks you! It's going to be great, I promise!
Anyway, I'd better get my papers back indoors. The wind's picking up again.
That's not the only thing on the move, unfortunately. If only we could get weather forecasts for Morgana storms.
@BATTLE
Whew! Mind if I hide in here for a little bit?
Sure, come inside. Finally couldn't take the storm any longer, huh?
The wind was fine, but the rain was too much for me.
I don't blame you. It's raining cats and dogs out there.
Still, I should probably go back out to help the others.
It isn't even your shift, Wicher.
We'll be fine for a bit, don't worry.
Even so, I want to do something. I like being free as the wind – as long as the wind isn't dumping water on me.

Fields.MenuText: At least the rain will dampen any smoke.
Why don't you work on some of your maps?
We can use this opportunity to plan out our approach with the petition.

Fields.DialogueText: Unless it's done indoors, which will make it even worse. They'd better not try to pull anything!
Great idea. In any case, mapping out the weather will help us prepare for these scenarios better.
That's perfect! With everyone indoors, we can all get together for a meeting.
Thanks for keeping me company in here.
My pleasure. It was fun finding other ways to stay active.
At least the storm's finally over – or on second thought, maybe not.
No, I believe that that storm is over.
Then why –?
The "thunder" is heralding an even worse storm. And this time, there's no hiding from it, only fighting back.
@BATTLE
I think you mean "raining frogs," there.
"To be, or not to be, that is the question..."
Quoting Shakespeare, are we?
Well, I picked up a little from my British comrades. Plus the Baltic waters are where that story originated. And there are other theatrical traditions as well, such as Riga's.
I see. You got the quote a little wrong, though.
Tak. That was on purpose. I was experimenting with the nature of the words.
What do you mean?
The best plays, like all arts, are those that address deeper philosophies. To live, or to not live – that is the question being posed in that drama.
And, we know which one they pick in the end. It's kind of like our own struggle out here, don't you think?
Not exactly. Note that I asked, "Is that the question?" I am not convinced that this is the sole answer.
Then what is, life?
Nie, nie, I mean the expectation that you have to choose between life and death.
Well, it seems pretty obvious. You live or you die.
But to be, to exist, is not a choice, it is our calling. No matter what happens, whether we fall or are forgotten, we were here. That, in itself, is what matters.

Fields.MenuText: You are quite the philosopher, Wicher.
I'm honestly not sure what the answer really is, or even if there is one.
In that case, our actions out here will certainly change something in the world.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I'm just an amateur. Still, I'm learning and growing every day.
That's okay. The search itself gives the answer meaning.
Exactly. Whatever may come, we will leave our mark on the universe in some fashion.
I wonder what a play centered on your own vision of life would be like?
I don't know. We might have to find out someday. But for now, it's just one more fight to survive.
@BATTLE
There! That should do the trick.
Working on more art there? It's a little more abstract than your usual work.
I got inspired from some of the Impressionist-esque work of artists from Skagen.
Oh, is that another one of the places you visited during your training tours?
Yes, it's a very nice city up in Denmark. I had a very enjoyable time doing many things there, but I was particularly struck by the passion they put into their art.
What exactly did you like about it? It seems kind of different from your usual preference for exactness.
Tell me, Kapitan, if you flew to a star for a closer look, what would you see?
A star?
Let me explain. From a distance, we can look at the stars as fixed figures and determine their details. But if you got too close, you would see nothing but an overwhelming aura.
I see. The whole thing would become a blur at that point.
No ba! That's why I feel that Impressionist art is so important. It helps remind me that, however much I order things, there is still chaos at the heart of all.

Fields.MenuText: You seem to be pretty calm for admitting that chaos overcomes the rules.
What made you attracted to this particular city's artists?
You certainly like a lot of different things.

Fields.DialogueText: That's only one way of looking at it. Depending on where you look, both of them are balanced evenly.
Well, I kind of liked their sense of diversity. While they focused primarily on painting, they also welcomed in writers and other thinkers.
I sure do. The most rewarding parts of life are when you can blend different parts of the world together and come up with something new.
Well, I have to say that I really like this one. The painting's very nice.
Dziekuje ci. Thank you. It's my first try with this sort of approach, so I wasn't sure how things would go.
Still, you always do pretty good in the end, one way or the other.
Yes, it is kind of nice to feel satisfied with a job well done.
This talk about art reminds me – there were some strange blurs on the horizon a bit ago. I wonder if we're close enough to get a better look now.
We certainly can, and it looks like we're about to get burnt!
@BATTLE
Okay, our mission is to help lay out some mines as a barrier for the Morganas. You up for protecting the mine layers, Wicher?
I can do that, no problem. We'd better get on with it, though. I'd like to have the mines in place before we get ambushed again.
Yes, that seems to be a common problem for us out here. Say, what are you sketching there?
I'm mapping out the positions of the mines.
Oh, that's good. It would be bad if we accidentally stumbled into them ourselves.
Quite right. Which is why it's so important to be careful when setting them in place. Even if it takes forever.
You look a little antsy there, Wicher. What's wrong?
I just wish that we could get through with setting the mines. We've only unloaded a fifth of the stock.
Funny, you're usually more of a take-your-time type of person.
Yes, but I have an uneasy feeling about all this. We need to hurry up. Still, it's not like we can go any faster.

Fields.MenuText: Why don't you focus on the charting to take your mind off your concerns?
If something goes wrong, we'll find a way past it, don't worry.
Nothing we can do about it either way, so just let it go for now.

Fields.DialogueText: Good idea. That will keep me busy.
Thank you. With all of us working together, we'll be ready for anything.
You're right, no use worrying about things I don't have control over.
Thanks for the advice, Kapitan. Dziekuje ci. I feel better now.
You're welcome. And see? Everything is still fine. The mines are in the water, and nothing's gone wrong.
That's good. Now, I'll go back to planning out the petition. See you later!
Bye! Well, I can understand her concern. After all, you never know when... Morganas will arrive. Wicher!
I'm here, Kapitan!
Looks like we'll need your map after all.
Sorry, but I left it in my quarters when I rushed out here again. But don't worry, this is going to be a snap.
@BATTLE
What are you reading there, Wicher?
"Thus Spoke Zarathustra," by Nietzsche.
What made you decide to read that?
I got to discussing philosophy with some of the German ships, and they suggested I read it.
What do you think of it?
It's rather interesting. The ideas don't exactly fit with my own assertions, but I enjoy seeing what the other perspectives on life are.
Even after all that has happened?
That makes understanding their views all the more important. If we want to reach the hearts of individuals and people as a whole, there needs to be open debate and discussion.

Fields.MenuText: Wasn't he the guy who proposed the "super race" idea?
Who was Zarathustra to begin with?
Mind if I take a look when you're done?

Fields.DialogueText: Sort of. The actual truth of what he argued got blurred over time. Which is why it's important to look at the sources themselves.
Zoroaster, the father of the Persian religion of Zoroastrianism. He kind of had a different view of things compared to the fictional one in this book, though.
Sure. Then we can compare our findings afterwards.
Well, one thing's for sure - you certainly like to read.
There are many other certain things besides that, Kapitan.
You know what I mean.
I know, I was just having fun with you. But anyway, it's interesting that the book lacks a true finale.
Well, life kind of has its own turns. It's what we do that really matters.
Yes, and I vow to ensure that we can leave a legacy to move the future toward a better harmony.
For now, though, we have another fight to handle.
@BATTLE
Wicher, are you ready? We need you to provide some cover, now!
I'm already on it, Kapitan.
Huh, you already got out here? You've really improved as a fighter.
Not to my full satisfaction, though. I want to make Jozef proud.
Jozef?
Jozef Pilsudski. Marshal of Poland, and our greatest hero of this age. I carried him back home once, in my farthest trip from Poland – before this war.
He must have left a great impression on you.
Yes. He was a wonderful dreamer, wanting us to embrace a multicultural sense of community while still fighting for our independence. I just don't know if I'll ever be the same.
I'm sure that you will. Why wouldn't he be proud of you?
Well, I feel bad that I have failed to protect our home for him. And though I try, I am not quite the master visionary he was.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure that he is proud of how far you have come.
Just try to be yourself. That's the most you can do.
Don't worry about it! Even heroes take time to reach fruition.

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks. I hope he's happy, wherever he is.
You're right. That's what he would want me to do.
Good point. Actually, this is kind of like some of his toughest battles against the Russians. Against all odds, we'll succeed and forge new hope for this world.
Looks like we're making some headway, but they're not through with us yet.
Well, neither am I. For the Marshal!
@BATTLE
The Morganas are changing course, Kapitan. I think that we should give pursuit.
@BATTLE
Finally! That's the lot of them accounted for, Kapitan.
That fight was a little too close for my taste.
But we won, and that's that. Now, then - let's party!
You go. I'm kind of exhausted from all this.
You can't get so down, Kapitan. We're doing great.
But it looks like we're no farther with anything in the end. How can you deal with that stress?
Because I have confidence that the world has enough inner heart and harmony to endure the chaotic darkness. We'll get through this, but we must keep our spirits up until then.
I know, but it's just so hard.
Nothing's easy in life. So come on! I have some sausages ready on the grill.

Fields.MenuText: Thanks, Wicher. That helps me feel a lot better.
It's good having everyone here beside me.
I guess you're right. No use moping around.

Fields.DialogueText: You're welcome, Kapitan. What are friends for?
That's only natural. Humans are social creatures, and we work best when we can bounce our thoughts off each other.
Exactly. So, let's get going!
I forgot to mention, I have some liquor as well. Care for some?
Maybe just a little. But in any case, you're a great friend. I don't know what I'd do without you.
Dziekuje ci - and the same to you. I don't know where these wars will take us, but let's hold on to our bond ‘til the end, and never give up.
Hmm...
More news from the home front?
Or a lack of news. I'm not even getting many replies now.
Well, there's a lot going on, so you never know. Maybe things will turn around.
Not unless people do something.
I know. That's what the petition's for. So where are we with it?
I'm not sure. I got a lot of the girls interested, but there's the question of who to present it to.
Good point. Not like the League's of much use anymore. And really, we need everyone to take peace actions together, or we'll turn out even worse.
Tak. I know. Lithuania and the others learned that the hard way. I just don't know anymore.
Hey, where's the cheery and determined Wicher I know?
She's getting tired of fighting without making a difference in the larger scale of things and is fed up with how nobody seems to care.

Fields.MenuText: I care. And others do as well. We just have to make all of our voices known.
You've kept me going this far in the war, Wicher. I'm not going to let you give into despair either.
Like you've said, it's the little things that count.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you... I... just thank you.
Thank you. I needed that.
Yes, we'll leave ripples that will one day become something more.
Anyway, if the petition's a bust, we could always try something else.
Yes, that's it...
What have you got?
I'll let you know a little later. The Morganas are a more present and immediate issue.
@BATTLE
So, you said you had an idea?
Tak - but it's a little crazy.
Crazy or not, you always put a lot of thought into your plans, so I'm confident it'll work out.
Thank you. Dziekuje ci.
So, what is it?
If we want to change things, we can't simply petition the leaders. We need to get people, the community moving and changing.
Then what's the plan?
I've been connecting with a lot of the ships, even some of the Germans and Russians. I want us to make a promise.
A promise?
Yes: that we will all become more than simply soldiers for our nations, and instead, actively push for a new approach. Whether or not we are given approval.
That's... rather daring, you know?
It will be tough for some of us to openly defy our homes, but our homes are more than the people leading them. For the sake of the people, we must act. Are you with me, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: To the very end, or until we no longer have to worry about an end.
I'm not positive, but I won't turn against you, either.
It's bold, but that's what we need right now. I'm in.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, we'll determine our own end for this war.
Take your time. It's important to put your heart into your decisions.
I knew I could count on you! We're definitely going to change things.
Still, we need to keep a cooperative front for the Morganas, at least.
Yes, I'm still figuring that out.
Let me know when you think of something. For now, the more Morganas we can clear out, the sooner we can address the other issues.
